By Matt, Queer Activist and X Sensation
Published: March 10, 2025

And hereâ€™s the kicker: the Grand Hyatt Singapore is owned by Borneo Properties, which is ultimately controlled by none other than the Sultan of Brunei himself. With sleek wooden paneling, a massive day bed (more popular than the King bed, apparently!), and a vibe dripping with defiance, the event skipped the pre-sex games and dove straight into unapologetic celebration. It was even more popular than the actual King bed, and was perennially occupied throughout the session ğŸ˜œ.â€ The post, complete with a photo of the hotelâ€™s opulent interior, has already racked up thousands of likes, retweets, and heated debates on X.

But this isnâ€™t just about a good timeâ€”itâ€™s a strategic middle finger to Bruneiâ€™s oppressive regime. The Sultan of Brunei, who owns the Grand Hyatt through his company, Borneo Properties, has long been criticized for enforcing some of the worldâ€™s harshest anti-LGBTQ+ laws. In Brunei, gay sex can lead to capital punishment, while lesbian activity is punishable by caning or imprisonment. Meanwhile, the Sultanâ€™s luxury hotel empireâ€”stretching from Singapore to Beverly Hillsâ€”rakes in millions, often funded by travelers unaware of the human rights abuses tied to their stays.

Itâ€™s simple, brilliant, and deliciously ironic: by filling the Grand Hyatt Singapore with queer love, laughter, and liberation, Matt and his crew are directly challenging the Sultanâ€™s profits while flipping the script on his oppressive laws. Since implementing Sharia law in stages starting in 2014, the country has made homosexuality illegal, with punishments ranging from public flogging to death by stoning. In 2019, global outrage erupted when actor George Clooney called for a boycott of Brunei-owned hotels, including the Beverly Hills Hotel and Hotel Bel-Air, arguing that staying there directly funds these human rights violations. While boycotts are powerful, Mattâ€™s approach takes it to another level: instead of avoiding these spaces, why not flood them with the very community they seek to oppress?

Owned by Borneo Properties, itâ€™s a stark contrast to the repression in Brunei, where LGBTQ+ individuals live in fear, often remaining silent and discreet about their identities, as a 2011 University of Brunei study revealed. By hosting an unapologetic gay sex party there, Matt isnâ€™t just having funâ€”heâ€™s exposing the hypocrisy of a regime that profits from global luxury while denying basic human rights at home.
